28.text:
Home to one 
of the largest protected areas in the world
(the Phoenix Islands Protected Area), Kiribati

49.text:
is the epitome of a tropical paradise. Independent
since 1979, Kiribati consists of a series

55.text:
of atolls and reefs with a smattering of little
islands perched on top. The temperatures are

60.text:
a pleasant low 80s, coconut and breadfruit
trees abound, and the waters are a lovely

66.text:
If you feel like booking a vacation in Kiribati,
however, you had better make it snappy. Owing

70.text:
to rising sea levels, two of its islands have
already been lost to the waves (Tebua Tarawa

74.text:
and Abanuea), and the rest are threatened.
While a few of the islands are expected to

79.text:
remain above water in 2115, what is left won’t
be able to support the agriculture needed

85.text:
The situation is desperate enough for President
Tong to begin evacuating the islands already

90.text:
(a process sped up by Cyclone Pam). Official
appeals have been made to Australia, New Zealand

95.text:
and Fiji to accept Kiribatians as permanent
refugees.

101.text:
It’s easy to imagine tropical nations disappearing
into the Pacific. What is less easily imagined

107.text:
is the loss of a European Nation to climate
change. Never-the-less, this is not only realistic,

112.text:
but in fact quite probable. Known as much
for its dikes as for being the place to go

116.text:
for legal drugs and prostitutes, much of the
Netherlands is below sea level.

121.text:
Unlike Kiribati, it is not simply rising sea
levels that threatens the Netherlands. An

125.text:
extremely modern nation with a powerful economy,
the Netherlands can well afford to continue

130.text:
expanding its dikes upwards to keep rising
seas out. The real problem is that the same

134.text:
dikes that can keep the sea out can keep flooding
in. With half the nation at or below one meter

140.text:
above sea level, the Netherlands has been
constantly fighting to keep its head above

144.text:
In 1953, A massive storm slammed into the
Netherlands and neighboring Belgium. Floods

149.text:
as deep as five-and-a-half meters deep swept
the southern parts of the country. Only the

153.text:
careful use of a ship to plug a dike prevented
the flooding of North Holland, the second

157.text:
most heavily populated province. With many
scientists predicting that previously “safe”

162.text:
Europe could soon be struck with frequent
“Hurricane Katrina” level storms, we’d

166.text:
book our Amsterdam holiday today if we were
you.

171.text:
What many people often tend to forget is that
Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II is not the

176.text:
Queen of England, she is the queen of the
United Kingdom. As early as Roman times attempts

181.text:
to unite the north and south of Britain had
failed (resulting in the building of a wall

184.text:
of Queen Elizabeth (the first one) in 1603
however led to parliament handing Scottish

189.text:
king James V the crown of England as well.
In 1707 the now 100 year old merger of the

194.text:
kingdom was formalized as “the United Kingdom
of Great Britain”.

198.text:
These days, however, one of the most successful
empires in history is facing a real possibility

203.text:
of dissolution. The union of the two kingdoms
began to show cracks as early as 1853, when

208.text:
advocates began calling for Home Rule. In
1934 Scottish nationalists formed the Scottish

214.text:
National Party, which has, of late, been a
champion of Scottish independence (and separate

221.text:
Referendums calling for the dissolution of
the United Kingdom have come up in Scotland

225.text:
roughly every 20 years since the 1970s. The
first failed on a technicality. The second

230.text:
was wildly popular, and finally established
the home rule that had been debated for nearly

234.text:
150 years, but did not actually dissolve the
union. The most recent (2014) failed by a

241.text:
narrow margin, but only six months later the
SNP swept the parliamentary elections on a

245.text:
wave of reaction to the narrow failure of
the referendum. With 56 out of 59 seats possible

251.text:
and opinion polls showing growing support
for another attempt, it seems likely that

255.text: the United Kingdom will be no more by 2115.

261.text:
Canada was the unhappy offspring of the Seven
Years’ War. While Great Britain and France

264.text:
were busy making a mess out of Europe from
1754-1763 their colonies in North America

271.text:
were having a pleasant, and related, brawl
of their own. The end result was the addition

275.text:
of New France’s fishing holes to the British
Empire. Unlike Scotland, where the two nations

280.text:
acted like loving newlyweds for a while, French
Canadians always approached things more like

287.text:
Though becoming British in 1763 it wasn’t
until 1840 that serious attempts were made

292.text:
to properly un-Frenchify them. French Canada
was merged with the rest of Canada, with their

297.text:
main population becoming the province of Quebec.
The French didn’t think much of this idea,

301.text:
but went along with it, mostly out of fear
of being invaded by the expansionists in the

306.text: U.S. (Reasonable, given its history with Mexico).

311.text:
In the post WWII world, the U.S. stopped seeming
to be the threat it had been, and the French

316.text:
Canadians haven’t really felt a particular
need to keep cooperating. Starting in the

320.text:
‘60s a significant percentage of Quebec
has been calling for sovereignty, led by the

324.text:
Parti Québécois. The most recent vote on
the issue failed by only 1% of the vote. With

330.text:
almost a quarter of the Canadian population,
most of the Atlantic ports, and total control

334.text:
of the St. Lawrence waterway, the loss of
Quebec could lead the rest of Canada splitting

338.text:
up under pressure from regional differences
and 1st Nation sovereignty movements.

345.text:
Taiwan is in an interesting position. While
many people are aware of the fact that China

349.text:
insists Taiwan is still a part of China, what
they don’t tend to recall is that Taiwan

354.text:
says the exact same thing. The only real debate
between the two is which government is the

358.text:
legitimate one, the pre-WWII Republic of China
government seated in Taiwan or the post war

364.text: People’s Republic of China in Beijing.

367.text:
Regardless of the politics, the fact is that,
in terms of actual operation, Taiwan is a

371.text:
wholly independent nation, and has acted as
such ever since Chang Kai-shek led his Kuomintang

376.text:
government to Taiwan in 1949. Despite its
own insistence it is not, it maintains diplomatic

382.text:
nations with many of the world’s nations,
it maintains its own military (purchasing

386.text:
heavily from trade partner America), it has
a democratically elected government that has

391.text:
unchallenged rule over the island. It walks
like a duck, and quacks like a duck…

396.text:
Still, the fact that both Taiwan and China
insist that Taiwan is just part of China goes

401.text:
a long way to removing the island’s nationhood.
Events over time have further eroded this

406.text:
position, such as the UN’s kicking Taiwan
out and giving China the empty seat in 1971.

412.text:
While there are some within Taiwan calling
for an official declaration of independence,

416.text:
the official government stance still calls
for eventual reunion with mainland China,

421.text:
and only 24% of the population responded favorably
to independence during a January poll. As

427.text:
such it is only a matter of time before Taiwan
returns to the fold.

433.text:
Just like China and Taiwan, North and South
Korea both insist on an eventual reunion.

438.text:
Unlike the first two, however, there is little
doubt about how the second two will eventually

442.text:
work out their reintegration. China and Taiwan
are both powerful in their own right, with

447.text:
strong economies, powerful technological potential,
and stable governments. On the Korean Peninsula,

453.text: on the other hand, such parity does not exist.

455.text:
North Korea, the result of the U.S.S.R. insisting
on having control over the northern half of

460.text:
Japan’s pre-WWII colony, is in the crapper.
Of the 193 member states of United Nations,

467.text:
North Korea’s per capita GDP comes in at
180th. The government runs entirely on the

473.text:
principle of the cult of personality, with
dictator Kim Jong-Un conducting near constant

478.text:
purges of the top ranks to keep things under
control. The only thing that North Korea can

482.text:
boast of is a strong military, and the few
high ranking defectors have spoken of coup

486.text:
attempts by the military that have been ruthlessly
kept out of the media.

490.text:
Most pundits consider it to only be a matter
of time before North Korea implodes under

494.text:
a weight of suspicion and backstabbing. When
that inevitable event occurs some time before

499.text:
2115, South Korea will be ready to take North
Korea back into a united country and start

504.text:
repairing the damage done by the Kim Klan,
as happened when East Germany was reunited

514.text:
Palestine occupies a strange position on the
family tree of nation-states today. While

518.text:
most of the top powers of the world do not
recognize it as a nation, more than two thirds

523.text:
of the UN’s member states do. Palestine
has a seat in the UN, though it does not have

527.text:
a vote. Its government has shockingly little
real power, as it often finds itself the subject

532.text:
of Israel’s wrath thanks to unilateral actions
on the part of radical groups inside its borders,

537.text:
but it has recognized borders, a standing
(if small) army, and a self-contained economy.

542.text:
Unfortunately, Palestine is the weakest kid
in a particularly bad neighborhood. Most of

546.text:
the country is occupied by Israel as a buffer
against terrorist groups. Jordan, sharing

551.text:
the other significant border with it, is a
stable nation, but has been struggling with

555.text:
the instability in nearby Syria and Iraq.
Jordan has been careful to be polite but standoffish

561.text:
in order to avoid buying even more border
trouble. Egypt has plenty of problems of its

566.text:
own, and Turkey and Iraq are both having big
trouble with ethnic separatists, so they are

570.text:
the last nations to be jumping aboard any
separatist support trains.

574.text:
Given the combination of Israeli hostility
and significant instability among the Arabic

578.text:
states close at hand, Palestine’s severe
governmental weakness is likely to result

583.text:
in Palestine becoming a failed state. Portions
that contain Israeli settlements will likely

588.text:
wind up fully annexed in spite of international
condemnation, while what remains could well

593.text:
wind up falling under the control of a UN
mandate, possibly regulated by Jordan. A Palestinian

599.text:
state is highly unlikely to exist as a national
entity in 2115.

605.text:
South Sudan is the newest nation in the world.
It is also likely to be one of the shortest

609.text:
lived nations in the world. It was formed
in 2011 after a referendum for independence

614.text:
from Sudan passed with nearly 99% of the vote.
That, however, was the one and only time anyone

620.text: seemed able to agree about anything.

622.text:
Externally, South Sudan can’t seem to nail
down any agreement regarding its border and

627.text:
trade relationship with Sudan. When it left,
it took all of Sudan’s oil fields, but Sudan

632.text:
retained all the infrastructure to transport
the oil away from those fields. Since then

637.text:
oil revenues have stagnated owing to a failure
to negotiate a profit sharing deal and both

642.text:
nations have had small proto-wars over how
to split up their resources.

646.text:
Internally, South Sudan hasn’t had any better
luck. 9 of its 10 provinces are suffering

650.text:
armed conflicts as various tribal and ethnic
groups fight one another, and all of them

655.text:
fight a government having a civil war with
itself. South Sudan is, at its heart, a microcosm

660.text:
of all the problems an increasingly overpopulated
world faces, and is unlikely to survive them

665.text:
for the next ten years, let alone long enough
to see 2115.

671.text:
If ever there was a nation that had bad luck,
it’s Haiti. Even before its war for independence,

675.text:
it was a bad luck state. Consisting mostly
of slaves at its start, Haiti has always suffered

680.text:
from nearly every problem that’s killing
the nations already listed so far. Haiti suffered

685.text:
from ethnic cleansing (courtesy of neighboring
Dominican Republic in the ’30s), has constantly

690.text:
suffered from severe poverty and the accompanying
armed revolts, and has been the object of

695.text:
affection of nearly every natural disaster
and disease imaginable. Then there are the

699.text:
All of these problems are now being compounded
by the same climate change threatening Kiribati

704.text:
and the Netherlands. Hurricanes are only growing
worse as the oceans warm, and Haiti is ground

709.text:
zero for any hurricane that doesn’t turn
towards the East Coast of the U.S. Between

713.text:
that, rising sea levels, desert generating
deforestation, and earthquakes substantial

718.text:
portions of Haiti are at threat of one mass
destruction too many.

722.text:
Seemingly doomed from the beginning, it is
perfectly reasonable for Haiti itself to become

726.text:
a zombie-like creature, not really alive,
but not really dead. Unable to recover from

731.text:
disasters economic and natural, Haiti may
well eventually resort to turning itself over

736.text:
to the UN or a better behaved Dominican Republic
out of a desperate hope that they may be able

740.text:
to keep something in that half of the island
alive in 2115.

747.text:
Sealand is a nation that has no chance of
seeing 2115, as it never really was a nation

751.text:
to begin with. When Germany demanded a rematch
with England, the embattled nation came up

756.text:
with some truly strange military ideas to
bring to the fight. Most of them never saw

761.text:
the light of day, but one that did was HM
Fort Roughs. Essentially two concrete pylons

767.text:
sunk into the English Channel six miles offshore,
the UK built a platform holding anti-aircraft

772.text:
guns to shoot down German bombers on the way
to the Blitz.

776.text:
After the war, the guns were removed and the
platform abandoned. In 1967 eccentric Paddy

780.text:
Bates took over the platform for use in pirate
radio. After an argument over a buoy led to

786.text:
the platform being raided by Her Majesty’s
Marines and the arrest of Paddy, the British

791.text:
courts declared that, as the platform was
three miles outside of the three mile limit,

795.text:
Britain had no control over the platform.
Paddy immediately took advantage of this and

799.text:
declared the creation of the Principality
of Sealand, with himself the reigning prince.

804.text:
After a dispute with “Prime Minister”
Alexander Achenbach led to the invasion of

808.text:
the platform by hired mercenaries, heir (and
current reigning prince) Michael Bates led

813.text:
a commando raid (consisting of himself, a
family friend, and a rented helicopter) to

817.text:
reclaim Sealand. Achenbach and his mercenaries
(all German citizens) were captured, and only

822.text:
released after Germany sent an ambassador
to negotiate their release.

826.text:
Owing to the British court decision and the
German ambassadorial mission, the Bates family

830.text:
has continued to maintain Sealand as an independent
“micro-nation.” However, without some

834.text:
serious intervention by both politicians and
engineers, Sealand won’t see 2115. In 1987

839.text:
the United Nations Convention on the Law of
the Sea extended all national sea borders

845.text:
from 3 miles out to 12 miles out, resulting
in Saeland now falling inside of British waters.

850.text:
At the same time, it specifically ruled that
artificial islands and structures cannot be

854.text:
recognized as establishing a territorial claim.
Though Britain has yet to act on this, that

860.text:
rule means that the U.K. can reclaim the platform
at any time, and the rest of the world will

864.text:
simply shrug. It may, however, be a moot point.
Recent research has shown that the global

868.text:
conditions created by climate change will
be far more destructive to concrete and iron.

873.text:
As such, it is likely the already somewhat
rotten structure may quickly become untenable.

878.text:
It is likely that long before 2115, Sealand
will become sea floor.
